item_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFNAME}: Operational status
item_prototypes.description: Reference: https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/networking/operstates.txt

trigger_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFNAME}: Link down
trigger_prototypes.description:
This trigger expression works as follows:
1. It can be triggered if the operations status is down.
2. `{$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1` - a user can redefine context macro to value - 0. That marks this interface as not important. No new trigger will be fired if this interface is down.
3. `{TEMPLATE_NAME:METRIC.diff()}=1` - the trigger fires only if the operational status was up to (1) sometime before (so, do not fire for the 'eternal off' interfaces.)

WARNING: if closed manually - it will not fire again on the next poll, because of .diff.

item_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFNAME}: Speed
item_prototypes.description:
It indicates the latest or current speed value of the interface. The value is an integer representing the link speed expressed in bits/sec.
This attribute is only valid for the interfaces that implement the ethtool `get_link_ksettings` method (mostly Ethernet).

Reference: https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/ABI/testing/sysfs-class-net

item_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFNAME}: Interface type
item_prototypes.description:
It indicates the interface protocol type as a decimal value.
See `include/uapi/linux/if_arp.h` for all possible values.
Reference: https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/ABI/testing/sysfs-class-net

trigger_prototypes.expression:
change(/Template-Training_Agent_Network interfaces/vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/speed"])<0 and last(/Template-Training_Agent_Network interfaces/vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/speed"])>0
and
(last(/Template-Training_Agent_Network interfaces/vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/type"])=6 or last(/Template-Training_Agent_Network interfaces/vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/type"])=1)
and
(last(/Template-Training_Agent_Network interfaces/vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/operstate"])<>2)
trigger_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFNAME}: Ethernet has changed to lower speed than it was before
trigger_prototypes.description: This Ethernet connection has transitioned down from its known maximum speed. This might be a sign of autonegotiation issues. Acknowledge to close the problem manually.

trigger_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFNAME}: High bandwidth usage
trigger_prototypes.description: The utilization of the network interface is close to its estimated maximum bandwidth.

trigger_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFNAME}: High error rate
trigger_prototypes.description: It recovers when it is below 80% of the `{$IF.ERRORS.WARN:"{#IFNAME}"}` threshold.

macros.description: Timeout after which agent is considered unavailable. Works only for agents reachable from Zabbix server/proxy (passive mode).
This macro is used as a threshold in the interface utilization trigger.
The CPU load per core is considered sustainable. If necessary, it can be tuned.
This macro is used as a threshold in the memory available trigger.
This macro is used as a threshold in the memory utilization trigger.
It filters out `loopbacks`, `nulls`, `docker veth` links and `docker0 bridge` by default.
This macro is used for a discovery of block devices. It can be overridden on host level or its linked template level.
This macro is used for a discovery of block devices. It can be overridden on host level or its linked template level.
The average response time (in ms) of disk read before the trigger would fire.
The average response time (in ms) of disk write before the trigger would fire.
The critical threshold for utilization of the filesystem.
The warning threshold for utilization of the filesystem.
This macro is used for discovery of the filesystems. It can be overridden on host level or its linked template level.
This macro is used for discovery of the filesystems. It can be overridden on host level or its linked template level.
This macro is used for discovery of the filesystems. It can be overridden on host level or its linked template level.
This macro is used for discovery of the filesystems. It can be overridden on host level or its linked template level.
The critical threshold of the filesystem metadata utilization.
The warning threshold of the filesystem metadata utilization.
The critical threshold of the filesystem utilization.
The warning threshold of the filesystem utilization.

templates.name: Template-Training_App_Apache_Tomcat_JMX
templates.description:
The template to monitor Apache Tomcat by Zabbix that work without any external scripts.
The metrics are collected by JMX.


You can discuss this template or leave feedback on our forum https://www.zabbix.com/forum/zabbix-suggestions-and-feedback/411862-discussion-thread-for-official-zabbix-template-tomcat

Template tooling version used: 0.38

items.name: Tomcat: Version
items.description: The version of the Tomcat.

triggers.name: Tomcat: Version has been changed
triggers.description: Tomcat version has changed. Ack to close.

item_prototypes.name: {#JMXVALUE}: Gzip compression status
item_prototypes.description: Gzip compression status on {#JMXNAME}. Enabling gzip compression may save server bandwidth.

trigger_prototypes.name: {#JMXVALUE}: Gzip compression is disabled
trigger_prototypes.description: gzip compression is disabled for connector {#JMXVALUE}.

item_prototypes.name: {#JMXNAME}: Bytes received per second
item_prototypes.description: Bytes received rate by processor {#JMXNAME}

item_prototypes.name: {#JMXNAME}: Bytes sent per second
item_prototypes.description: Bytes sent rate by processor {#JMXNAME}

item_prototypes.name: {#JMXNAME}: Errors per second
item_prototypes.description: Error rate of request processor {#JMXNAME}

item_prototypes.name: {#JMXNAME}: Requests processing time
item_prototypes.description: The total time to process all incoming requests of request processor {#JMXNAME}

item_prototypes.name: {#JMXNAME}: Requests per second
item_prototypes.description: Rate of requests served by request processor {#JMXNAME}

item_prototypes.name: {#JMXHOST}{#JMXCONTEXT}: Sessions active
item_prototypes.description: Active sessions of the application.

item_prototypes.name: {#JMXHOST}{#JMXCONTEXT}: Sessions allowed maximum
item_prototypes.description: The maximum number of active Sessions allowed, or -1 for no limit.

item_prototypes.name: {#JMXHOST}{#JMXCONTEXT}: Sessions active maximum so far
item_prototypes.description: Maximum number of active sessions so far.

item_prototypes.name: {#JMXHOST}{#JMXCONTEXT}: Sessions rejected per second
item_prototypes.description: Rate of sessions we rejected due to maxActive being reached.

item_prototypes.name: {#JMXHOST}{#JMXCONTEXT}: Sessions created per second
item_prototypes.description: Rate of sessions created by this application per second.

item_prototypes.name: {#JMXNAME}: Threads count
item_prototypes.description: Amount of threads the thread pool has right now, both busy and free.

item_prototypes.name: {#JMXNAME}: Threads busy
item_prototypes.description: Number of the requests that are being currently handled.

item_prototypes.name: {#JMXNAME}: Threads limit
item_prototypes.description: Limit of the threads count. When currentThreadsBusy counter reaches the maxThreads limit, no more requests could be handled, and the application chokes.

trigger_prototypes.name: {#JMXNAME}: Busy worker threads count are more than {$TOMCAT.THREADS.MAX.PCT:"{#JMXNAME}"}% of the limit for {$TOMCAT.THREADS.MAX.TIME:"{#JMXNAME}"}
trigger_prototypes.description: When current threads busy counter reaches the limit, no more requests could be handled, and the application chokes.

macros.description: Filter for discoverable objects. Can be used with following contexts: "GlobalRequestProcessor", "ThreadPool", "Manager"
Filter to exclude discovered objects. Can be used with following contexts: "GlobalRequestProcessor", "ThreadPool", "Manager"
Password for JMX
Threshold for busy worker threads trigger. Can be used with {#JMXNAME} as context.
The time during which the number of busy threads can exceed the threshold. Can be used with {#JMXNAME} as context.
User for JMX

items.name: ClassLoading: Loaded class count
items.description: Displays number of classes that are currently loaded in the Java virtual machine.

items.name: ClassLoading: Total loaded class count
items.description: Displays the total number of classes that have been loaded since the Java virtual machine has started execution.

items.name: ClassLoading: Unloaded class count
items.description: Displays the total number of classes that have been loaded since the Java virtual machine has started execution.

items.name: Compilation: Name of the current JIT compiler
items.description: Displays the total number of classes unloaded since the Java virtual machine has started execution.

items.name: Compilation: Accumulated time spent
items.description: Displays the approximate accumulated elapsed time spent in compilation, in seconds.

items.name: GarbageCollector: Copy number of collections per second
items.description: Displays the total number of collections that have occurred per second.

items.name: GarbageCollector: Copy accumulated time spent in collection
items.description: Displays the approximate accumulated collection elapsed time, in seconds.

items.name: GarbageCollector: MarkSweepCompact number of collections per second
items.description: Displays the total number of collections that have occurred per second.

items.name: GarbageCollector: MarkSweepCompact accumulated time spent in collection
items.description: Displays the approximate accumulated collection elapsed time, in seconds.

items.name: Memory: Heap memory committed
items.description: Current heap memory allocated. This amount of memory is guaranteed for the Java virtual machine to use.

items.name: Memory: Heap memory maximum size
items.description: Maximum amount of heap that can be used for memory management. This amount of memory is not guaranteed to be available if it is greater than the amount of committed memory. The Java virtual machine may fail to allocate memory even if the amount of used memory does not exceed this maximum size.

items.name: Memory: Heap memory used
items.description: Current memory usage outside the heap.

items.name: Memory: Non-Heap memory committed
items.description: Current memory allocated outside the heap. This amount of memory is guaranteed for the Java virtual machine to use.

items.name: Memory: Non-Heap memory used
items.description: Current memory usage outside the heap

items.name: Memory: Object pending finalization count
items.description: The approximate number of objects for which finalization is pending.

items.name: MemoryPool: Code Cache committed
items.description: Current memory allocated

items.name: MemoryPool: CodeCache maximum size
items.description: Maximum amount of memory that can be used for memory management. This amount of memory is not guaranteed to be available if it is greater than the amount of committed memory. The Java virtual machine may fail to allocate memory even if the amount of used memory does not exceed this maximum size.

items.name: MemoryPool: Code Cache used
items.description: Current memory usage

items.name: MemoryPool: Tenured Gen committed
items.description: Current memory allocated

items.name: MemoryPool: Tenured Gen maximum size
items.description: Maximum amount of memory that can be used for memory management. This amount of memory is not guaranteed to be available if it is greater than the amount of committed memory. The Java virtual machine may fail to allocate memory even if the amount of used memory does not exceed this maximum size.

items.name: MemoryPool: Tenured Gen used
items.description: Current memory usage

items.name: OperatingSystem: File descriptors maximum count
items.description: This is the number of file descriptors we can have opened in the same process, as determined by the operating system. You can never have more file descriptors than this number.

items.name: OperatingSystem: File descriptors opened
items.description: This is the number of opened file descriptors at the moment, if this reaches the MaxFileDescriptorCount, the application will throw an IOException: Too many open files. This could mean you’re are opening file descriptors and never closing them.

items.name: OperatingSystem: Process CPU Load
items.description: ProcessCpuLoad represents the CPU load in this process.

triggers.name: OperatingSystem: Process CPU Load more than {$JMX.CPU.LOAD.MAX}% for {$JMX.CPU.LOAD.TIME}

items.name: Threading: Daemon thread count
items.description: Number of daemon threads running.

items.name: Threading: Peak thread count
items.description: Maximum number of threads being executed at the same time since the JVM was started or the peak was reset.

items.name: Threading: Thread count
items.description: The number of threads running at the current moment.

items.name: Threading: Total started thread count
items.description: The number of threads started since the JVM was launched.

macros.description: A threshold in percent for CPU utilization trigger.
The time during which the CPU utilization may exceed the threshold.
A threshold in percent for file descriptors count trigger.
The time during which the file descriptors count may exceed the threshold.
A threshold in percent for Heap memory utilization trigger.
The time during which the Heap memory utilization may exceed the threshold.
A threshold in percent for memory pools utilization trigger. Use a context to change the threshold for a specific pool.
The time during which the memory pools utilization may exceed the threshold.
A threshold in percent for Non-heap memory utilization trigger.
The time during which the Non-heap memory utilization may exceed the threshold.

items.name: Zabbix DB size
items.params: select SUM(data_length) from information_schema.tables where table_schema = 'zabbix'

items.name: Zabbix Server - count of unsupported items

macros.description: User pass zbx_probe (cat /root/zbx_probe.pw)
MySQL user pass zbx_probe (cat /root/mysql-zbx_probe.pw)

templates.name: Template-Training_MySQL_by_Zabbix_agent_2
templates.description:
Requirements for template operation:
1. Create MySQL user for monitoring. For example:
CREATE USER 'zbx_monitor'@'%' IDENTIFIED BY '<password>';
GRANT REPLICATION CLIENT,PROCESS,SHOW DATABASES,SHOW VIEW ON *.* TO 'zbx_monitor'@'%';
For more information please read the MySQL documentation https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/grant.html.
2. Set in the {$MYSQL.DSN} macro the data source name of the MySQL instance either session name from Zabbix agent 2 configuration file or URI.
Examples: MySQL1, tcp://localhost:3306, tcp://172.16.0.10, unix:/var/run/mysql.sock
For more information about MySQL Unix socket file please read the MySQL documentation https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/problems-with-mysql-sock.html.
3. If you had set URI in the {$MYSQL.DSN}, please define the user name and password in host macros ({$MYSQL.USER} and {$MYSQL.PASSWORD}).
Leave macros {$MYSQL.USER} and {$MYSQL.PASSWORD} empty if you use a session name. Set the user name and password in the Plugins.Mysql.<...> section of your Zabbix agent 2 configuration file.
For more information about configuring the Zabbix MySQL plugin please read the documentation https://git.zabbix.com/projects/ZBX/repos/zabbix/browse/src/go/plugins/mysql/README.md.


You can discuss this template or leave feedback on our forum https://www.zabbix.com/forum/zabbix-suggestions-and-feedback/384189-discussion-thread-for-official-zabbix-template-db-mysql

Template tooling version used: 0.41

items.name: MySQL: Aborted clients per second
items.description: Number of connections that were aborted because the client died without closing the connection properly.

items.name: MySQL: Aborted connections per second
items.description: Number of failed attempts to connect to the MySQL server.

triggers.name: MySQL: Server has aborted connections
triggers.event_name: MySQL: Server has aborted connections (over {$MYSQL.ABORTED_CONN.MAX.WARN} for 5m)
triggers.description: The number of failed attempts to connect to the MySQL server is more than {$MYSQL.ABORTED_CONN.MAX.WARN} in the last 5 minutes.

items.name: MySQL: Binlog cache disk use
items.description: Number of transactions that used a temporary disk cache because they could not fit in the regular binary log cache, being larger than binlog_cache_size.

items.name: MySQL: Buffer pool efficiency
items.description: The item shows how effectively the buffer pool is serving reads.

items.name: MySQL: Buffer pool utilization
items.description: Ratio of used to total pages in the buffer pool.

triggers.name: MySQL: Buffer pool utilization is too low
triggers.event_name: MySQL: Buffer pool utilization is too low (less than {$MYSQL.BUFF_UTIL.MIN.WARN}% for 5m)
triggers.description: The buffer pool utilization is less than {$MYSQL.BUFF_UTIL.MIN.WARN}% in the last 5 minutes. This means that there is a lot of unused RAM allocated for the buffer pool, which you can easily reallocate at the moment.

items.name: MySQL: Bytes received
items.description: Number of bytes received from all clients.

items.name: MySQL: Bytes sent
items.description: Number of bytes sent to all clients.

items.name: MySQL: Command Delete per second
items.description: The Com_delete counter variable indicates the number of times the delete statement has been executed.

items.name: MySQL: Command Insert per second
items.description: The Com_insert counter variable indicates the number of times the insert statement has been executed.

items.name: MySQL: Command Select per second
items.description: The Com_select counter variable indicates the number of times the select statement has been executed.

items.name: MySQL: Command Update per second
items.description: The Com_update counter variable indicates the number of times the update statement has been executed.

items.name: MySQL: Connections per second
items.description: Number of connection attempts (successful or not) to the MySQL server.

items.name: MySQL: Connection errors accept per second
items.description: Number of errors that occurred during calls to accept() on the listening port.

items.name: MySQL: Connection errors internal per second
items.description: Number of refused connections due to internal server errors, for example, out of memory errors, or failed thread starts.

items.name: MySQL: Connection errors max connections per second
items.description: Number of refused connections due to the max_connections limit being reached.

triggers.name: MySQL: Refused connections
triggers.description: Number of refused connections due to the max_connections limit being reached.

items.name: MySQL: Connection errors peer address per second
items.description: Number of errors while searching for the connecting client IP address.

items.name: MySQL: Connection errors select per second
items.description: Number of errors during calls to select() or poll() on the listening port. The client would not necessarily have been rejected in these cases.

items.name: MySQL: Connection errors tcpwrap per second
items.description: Number of connections the libwrap library has refused.

items.name: MySQL: Created tmp tables on disk per second
items.description: Number of internal on-disk temporary tables created by the server while executing statements.

triggers.name: MySQL: Number of on-disk temporary tables created per second is high
triggers.event_name: MySQL: Number of on-disk temporary tables created per second is high (over {$MYSQL.CREATED_TMP_DISK_TABLES.MAX.WARN} for 5m)
triggers.description: Possibly the application using the database is in need of query optimization.

items.name: MySQL: Created tmp files on disk per second
items.description: How many temporary files mysqld has created.

triggers.name: MySQL: Number of temporary files created per second is high
triggers.event_name: MySQL: Number of temporary files created per second is high (over {$MYSQL.CREATED_TMP_FILES.MAX.WARN} for 5m)
triggers.description: Possibly the application using the database is in need of query optimization.

items.name: MySQL: Created tmp tables on memory per second
items.description: Number of internal temporary tables created by the server while executing statements.

triggers.name: MySQL: Number of internal temporary tables created per second is high
triggers.event_name: MySQL: Number of internal temporary tables created per second is high (over {$MYSQL.CREATED_TMP_TABLES.MAX.WARN} for 5m)
triggers.description: Possibly the application using the database is in need of query optimization.

items.name: MySQL: Get status variables
items.description: The item gets server global status information.

items.name: MySQL: InnoDB buffer pool pages free
items.description: The total size of the InnoDB buffer pool, in pages.

items.name: MySQL: InnoDB buffer pool pages total
items.description: The total size of the InnoDB buffer pool, in pages.

items.name: MySQL: InnoDB buffer pool reads
items.description: Number of logical reads that InnoDB could not satisfy from the buffer pool, and had to read directly from the disk.

items.name: MySQL: InnoDB buffer pool reads per second
items.description: Number of logical reads per second that InnoDB could not satisfy from the buffer pool, and had to read directly from the disk.

items.name: MySQL: InnoDB buffer pool read requests
items.description: Number of logical read requests.

items.name: MySQL: InnoDB buffer pool read requests per second
items.description: Number of logical read requests per second.

items.name: MySQL: Innodb buffer pool wait free
items.description: Number of times InnoDB waited for a free page before reading or creating a page. Normally, writes to the InnoDB buffer pool happen in the background. When no clean pages are available, dirty pages are flushed first in order to free some up. This counts the numbers of wait for this operation to finish. If this value is not small, look at the increasing innodb_buffer_pool_size.

items.name: MySQL: Calculated value of innodb_log_file_size
items.description: Calculated by (innodb_os_log_written-innodb_os_log_written(time shift -1h))/{$MYSQL.INNODB_LOG_FILES} value of the innodb_log_file_size. Innodb_log_file_size is the size in bytes of the each InnoDB redo log file in the log group. The combined size can be no more than 512GB. Larger values mean less disk I/O due to less flushing checkpoint activity, but also slower recovery from a crash.

items.name: MySQL: Innodb number open files
items.description: Number of open files held by InnoDB. InnoDB only.

items.name: MySQL: Innodb log written
items.description: Number of bytes written to the InnoDB log.

items.name: MySQL: InnoDB row lock time
items.description: The total time spent in acquiring row locks for InnoDB tables, in milliseconds.

items.name: MySQL: InnoDB row lock time max
items.description: The maximum time to acquire a row lock for InnoDB tables, in milliseconds.

items.name: MySQL: InnoDB row lock waits
items.description: Number of times operations on InnoDB tables had to wait for a row lock.

items.name: MySQL: Max used connections
items.description: The maximum number of connections that have been in use simultaneously since the server start.

items.name: MySQL: Open tables
items.description: Number of tables that are open.

items.name: MySQL: Open table definitions
items.description: Number of cached table definitions.

items.name: MySQL: Queries per second
items.description: Number of statements executed by the server. This variable includes statements executed within stored programs, unlike the Questions variable.

items.name: MySQL: Questions per second
items.description: Number of statements executed by the server. This includes only statements sent to the server by clients and not statements executed within stored programs, unlike the Queries variable.

items.name: MySQL: Slow queries per second
items.description: Number of queries that have taken more than long_query_time seconds.

triggers.name: MySQL: Server has slow queries
triggers.event_name: MySQL: Server has slow queries (over {$MYSQL.SLOW_QUERIES.MAX.WARN} for 5m)
triggers.description: The number of slow queries is more than {$MYSQL.SLOW_QUERIES.MAX.WARN} in the last 5 minutes.

items.name: MySQL: Threads cached
items.description: Number of threads in the thread cache.

items.name: MySQL: Threads connected
items.description: Number of currently open connections.

items.name: MySQL: Threads created per second
items.description: Number of threads created to handle connections. If Threads_created is big, you may want to increase the thread_cache_size value. The cache miss rate can be calculated as Threads_created/Connections.

items.name: MySQL: Threads running
items.description: Number of threads which are not sleeping.

items.name: MySQL: Uptime
items.description: The amount of seconds that the server has been up.

triggers.name: MySQL: Failed to fetch info data
triggers.event_name: MySQL: Failed to fetch info data (or no data for 30m)
triggers.description: Zabbix has not received data for items for the last 30 minutes.

triggers.name: MySQL: Service has been restarted
triggers.description: MySQL uptime is less than 10 minutes.

triggers.name: MySQL: Version has changed
triggers.event_name: MySQL: Version has changed (new version value received: {ITEM.VALUE})
triggers.description: MySQL version has changed. Ack to close.

discovery_rules.name: MariaDB discovery
discovery_rules.description: Additional metrics if MariaDB is used.

item_prototypes.name: MySQL: Binlog commits
item_prototypes.description: Total number of transactions committed to the binary log.

item_prototypes.name: MySQL: Binlog group commits
item_prototypes.description: Total number of group commits done to the binary log.

item_prototypes.name: MySQL: Master GTID wait count
item_prototypes.description: The number of times MASTER_GTID_WAIT called.

item_prototypes.name: MySQL: Master GTID wait timeouts
item_prototypes.description: Number of timeouts occurring in MASTER_GTID_WAIT.

item_prototypes.name: MySQL: Master GTID wait time
item_prototypes.description: Total number of time spent in MASTER_GTID_WAIT.

discovery_rules.name: Replication discovery
discovery_rules.description: If "show slave status" returns Master_Host, "Replication: *" items are created.

item_prototypes.name: MySQL: Replication Slave status {#MASTER_HOST}
item_prototypes.description: The item gets status information on the essential parameters of the slave threads.

item_prototypes.name: MySQL: Replication Seconds Behind Master {#MASTER_HOST}
item_prototypes.description:
Number of seconds that the slave SQL thread is behind processing the master binary log.
A high number (or an increasing one) can indicate that the slave is unable to handle events
from the master in a timely fashion.

trigger_prototypes.name: MySQL: Replication lag is too high
trigger_prototypes.event_name: MySQL: Replication lag is too high (over {$MYSQL.REPL_LAG.MAX.WARN} for 5m)

item_prototypes.name: MySQL: Replication Slave IO Running {#MASTER_HOST}
item_prototypes.description:
Whether the I/O thread for reading the master's binary log is running.
Normally, you want this to be Yes unless you have not yet started a replication or have
explicitly stopped it with STOP SLAVE.

trigger_prototypes.name: MySQL: The slave I/O thread is not connected to a replication master

dependencies.name: MySQL: The slave I/O thread is not running

trigger_prototypes.name: MySQL: The slave I/O thread is not running
trigger_prototypes.description: Whether the I/O thread for reading the master's binary log is running.

item_prototypes.name: MySQL: Replication Slave SQL Running {#MASTER_HOST}
item_prototypes.description:
Whether the SQL thread for executing events in the relay log is running.
As with the I/O thread, this should normally be Yes.

trigger_prototypes.name: MySQL: The SQL thread is not running
trigger_prototypes.description: Whether the SQL thread for executing events in the relay log is running.

dependencies.name: MySQL: The slave I/O thread is not running

item_prototypes.name: MySQL: Replication Slave SQL Running State {#MASTER_HOST}
item_prototypes.description: This shows the state of the SQL driver threads.

triggers.name: Zarizeni je nedostupne po siti
triggers.description: Zarizeni neodpovida na ICMP ping. Overte sitovou dostupnost zarizeni.

triggers.name: Jmeno zarizeni bylo zmeneno
triggers.description: Upozorneni na zmenu SNMP sysName zarizeni.

triggers.name: Zarizeni je nedostupne pro monitoring
triggers.description: SNMP data ze zarizeni nejsou dostupna dele nez 15 minut.

items.name: Registered number of network interfaces
items.description: The number of network interfaces (regardless of their current state) present on this system.

discovery_rules.name: Network interfaces
discovery_rules.description:
You may also consider using {#SNMPVALUE} macro to filter results.

{$SNMP_COMMUNITY} is a global macro.

item_prototypes.name: Admin status
item_prototypes.description: The desired state of the interface.

item_prototypes.name: Description
item_prototypes.description: A textual string containing information about the interface.  This string should include the name of the manufacturer, the product name and the version of the interface hardware/software.

item_prototypes.name: Inbound errors
item_prototypes.description: For packet-oriented interfaces, the number of inbound packets that contained errors preventing them from being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol.  For character-oriented or fixed-length interfaces, the number of inbound transmission units that contained errors preventing them from being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol.

item_prototypes.name: Incoming traffic
item_prototypes.description: The number of octets in valid MAC frames received on this interface, including the MAC header and FCS.

item_prototypes.name: Operational status
item_prototypes.description: The current operational state of the interface.

item_prototypes.name: Outbound discards
item_prototypes.description: The number of outbound packets which were chosen to be discarded even though no errors had been detected to prevent their being transmitted.  One possible reason for discarding such a packet could be to free up buffer space.

item_prototypes.name: Outbound errors
item_prototypes.description: For packet-oriented interfaces, the number of outbound packets that could not be transmitted because of errors. For character-oriented or fixed-length interfaces, the number of outbound transmission units that could not be transmitted because of errors.

item_prototypes.name: Outgoing traffic
item_prototypes.description: The number of octets transmitted in MAC frames on this interface, including the MAC header and FCS.

triggers.name: GarbageCollector: Mark Sweep Compact in fire fighting mode
Memory: Heap memory usage more than {$JMX.HEAP.USAGE.MAX}% for {$JMX.HEAP.MEM.USAGE.TIME}
MemoryPool: Code Cache memory usage more than {$JMX.MP.USAGE.MAX:"Code Cache"}% for {$JMX.MP.USAGE.TIME:"Code Cache"}
MemoryPool: Tenured Gen memory usage more than {$JMX.MP.USAGE.MAX:"Tenured Gen"}% for {$JMX.MP.USAGE.TIME:"Tenured Gen"}
OperatingSystem: Opened file descriptor count more than {$JMX.FILE.DESCRIPTORS.MAX}% of maximum

graphs.name: GarbageCollector: Garbage Collector collections per second
